info.title: TinEye API
info.description: # What is the TinEye API ## Introduction The TinEye API provides a programmatic interface to search the [TinEye](https://tineye.com/) index. Search results include the following details: - a count of the total number of matches - a direct URL to each matching image - the URL of the page where each match was found - if the source is a [collection](https://help.tineye.com/article/251-what-are-image-collections) or [stock](https://help.tineye.com/article/252-what-are-stock-images) site - the [score](#tag--Search-the-TinEye-index--score) for the individual match - a link to the ‘compare images’ [overlay image](#tag--Search-the-TinEye-index--image-overlays) If you don’t need to build a custom application, you can use the TinEye API web interface at [tineye.com/api-search](https://tineye.com/api-search). For more information, check out our guide to [using the TinEye API without writing any code.](https://help.tineye.com/article/188-using-the-tineye-api-without-writing-any-code) ## Examples The TinEye API can find versions of images even if they've been modified. For example, here is the "melon cat" image we use in our API [sandbox](#overview--api-sandbox): ![meloncat](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/meloncat.jpg) And here are some matches that the TinEye API returns when you search for that image: ![example1](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/meloncat-result-b43aa925.jpg) ![example2](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/meloncat-result-73b78db1.jpg) ![example3](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/meloncat-result-37261ee0.jpg) ![example4](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/meloncat-result-240948fe.jpg) ## API Description The service is delivered over HTTP or HTTPS as a [REST](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_state_transfer) API, with responses delivered in [JSON](http://json.org/) format. The API is entirely independent of your operating system, database system or development language. ## Libraries Libraries for the TinEye API are available in the following languages and frameworks: - [Node.js](https://www.npmjs.com/package/tineye-api) - [PHP](https://packagist.org/packages/tineye/tineye-api) - [Python](https://github.com/TinEye/pytineye) - [Ruby](https://rubygems.org/gems/tinplate/) (unofficial library by [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com/)) If you have comments, recommendations, bug reports or a library that you would like featured here, please contact us. If you find a bug with a third-party library, please contact the developer directly. ## Support If you require assistance or have questions, please [get in touch](https://services.tineye.com/support) or email us at [support@tineye.com](mailto:support%40tineye.com) You can also explore our [Help Centre](https://help.tineye.com/category/168-getting-started) for additional guidance on working with the TinEye API. # Getting started This guide will help you through the steps to integrate the TinEye API with your code: - [Sign up](#overview--signing-up) for a TinEye API account and purchase a search bundle - [Get your API key](#overview--getting-your-api-key) to connect your code to your TinEye API account - [Perform a test search](#tag--Search-the-TinEye-index) to make sure everything is working properly If you plan on using TinEye to identify stock photos, you may also want to check out our [article](https://help.tineye.com/article/182-using-the-tineye-api-to-determine-if-an-image-is-a-stock-photo) on Identifying stock photos. ## Signing up Before you can search with the TinEye API, you must [sign up for an account](https://services.tineye.com/TinEyeAPI#plans-and-pricing) and buy your first search bundle. You can still test your code without signing up by using our [API sandbox](#overview--api-sandbox). The sandbox lets you try the code without using searches, but it will return fake results. ## Getting your API key Once you've signed up for an account, you can get your API key by signing in to your TinEye API account and going to the [Getting started](https://tineye.com/getting-started) page. Your key is used to authenticate your API requests and should always be kept secret. ## Writing code to call the API Now that you've signed up and purchased a bundle, it's time to write some code! Ensure your code calls our API from a server-side script, as client-side requests expose your key to the end-user. # API Sandbox The sandbox is a testing environment that you can use to aid your integration of the TinEye API. We recommend testing your requests and whether your code handles responses correctly before using the production API. Searches done using the sandbox will not count toward your search limit. ## Authentication Each request to the TinEye API must be authenticated. Add the custom header `X-API-KEY` to your request with your API key as the value. The sandbox can be used with: - URL: [https://api.tineye.com/rest/](https://api.tineye.com/rest) - Sandbox API key: `6mm60lsCNIBqFwOWjJqA80QZHh9BMwc-ber4u=t^` ## Differences between the sandbox and production environments ### `/search/` The search method will only return results for the "melon cat" image, no matter what image URL or image data you supply. ![meloncat](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/meloncat.jpg) The melon cat results are not static; you will be able to try out other arguments to the search such as `offset`, `limit`, etc. However, the sandbox cannot reproduce all the errors that can be returned by the TinEye API, since it is forced to use a good image.

matches.description: Images that matched the query image

backlink.description: Webpage URL where the match was found.

backlinks.description: Links to the original website and image URL.

query_match_percent.description:
The [percentage](#tag--Search-the-TinEye-index--query_match_percent) 
of the query image that matches the result image.

domain.description: Domain this result was found on.

total_filtered_results.description: Number of results after applying domain and tag filters.

bundles.description: List of non-expired bundles with remaining searches.

total_remaining_searches.description: Total number of searches remaining across all non-expired bundles.

remaining_searches.description: Number of remaining searches available in this bundle.

end_date.description: End date of this bundle, when it will deactivate.

results.description: Number of images indexed by TinEye.

timestamp.description: Unix timestamp of when the query took place.

query_time.description: Time it took to run this query in milliseconds.

X-API-KEY.name: X-API-KEY
X-API-KEY.description: All API requests must be authenticated by including the `X-API-KEY` header with your API key. Your API key can be found by logging in to your account and visiting the Getting started page.

pretty.name: pretty
pretty.description:
When "true", the response json is returned with line-breaks
and indentation for easier reading.

offset.name: offset
offset.description:
Offset from the beginning of the results.
This can be used with `limit` to page through results.

limit.name: limit
limit.description: Maximum number of results to return. A value of 0 removes the limit.

backlink_limit.name: backlink_limit
backlink_limit.description: Maximum number of backlinks to return per match.  A value of 0 removes the limit. Use caution when removing the limit, as some matches may have a huge number of backlinks.

sort.name: sort
sort.description: Sort by score, file size (width x height), or the date the image was added to the index.

order.name: order
order.description: Sort results in ascending ("asc") or descending ("desc") order.

domain.name: domain
domain.description: Only show results from the specified domain. Accepted values must be at least 5 characters and must be a complete domain name (e.g., amazon.com, not amazon).

tags.name: Search the TinEye index
tags.description:
## Image formats and sizes Search images must be in JPEG, PNG, WebP, GIF, BMP, AVIF, or TIFF format. We do not support animations. Images that are too small or have very little visual detail will not return any search results. For optimal performance, uploaded images should be 300px in size in the smallest dimension. For example, 600×400 pixels is larger than required and will be resized by our servers. It will take longer to transfer this file to the TinEye API. It would be more efficient to resize this image to be 450×300 before sending it to the API. ## API rate limiting Depending on the load being experienced by the TinEye servers, you may receive a “429 Too many requests” error when making many simultaneous searches. Please ensure that your code can either handle that error, or that it waits for the current search to complete before performing the next search. If you regularly need to perform a high number of concurrent searches, please contact us with details about your requirements. ## Result fields ### score Each result includes a score from 0 to 100, indicating how closely the result image matches the query image. By default, results are sorted in descending order, with the strongest match appearing first. Weaker scores can result from partial matches, where only a logo, text, or background aligns rather than the full image. They can also result from changes in size, such as an otherwise identical image that has been resized or cropped. A low score does not necessarily mean the match is irrelevant; it may simply indicate a difference in image size. We generally recommend against using a score threshold to filter results because this can remove good matches. An exact image resized into a thumbnail may have a lower score than a heavily modified version at its original size. While high-volume users may choose to set a score cutoff, this approach is not always recommended if detecting small or altered images is important. For example, here is an original image: ![original_citrus](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/citrus_original.jpg) When searching for this image, you may find matches where the image is cropped or resized: ![citrus_matches](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/citrus_crop_and_thumb.jpg) These are valid matches, but their scores are only 22.4 and 24.7, respectively. On the other hand, consider the following matching images: ![humingbird](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/hummingbird.jpg) These are clearly two different images, yet the match score is 51.4—significantly higher than the legitimate matches shown above. ### query_match_percent Each result includes a query_match_percent with a value between 0 and 100, representing the percentage of the query image that matches the result image. Due to how matching regions are identified and compared, this is usually less than 100, even for visually identical images. If the query_match_percent is very low, it means that only a small portion of the query image matches the result. In use cases where small matches, such as logos or tiny details, are not relevant, a low query_match_percent can be safely interpreted as an insignificant match. You can find more guidance on using the query_match_percent in this [article](https://help.tineye.com/article/289-tineye-api-results-querymatchpercent). ### Image overlays Each result will include a URL to generate an overlay image on the API server that aligns the search and result images, adjusting for crops, flips, translations and rotation so that they match. To view the overlay, browse the URL (e.g. `https://api.tineye.com/rest/`). You can use this URL to link to the overlay image directly in the src attribute of an HTML img tag. ![sample_overlay](https://api.tineye.com/rest/docs/img/sample_overlay.jpg) The left side of the overlay is the matched image. The right side is the search image. Using JavaScript and CSS, you can use the overlay image to easily see how the two images differ.
Example code: ```html
``` The example code above shows the left half of the overlay image to start (i.e., the matched image) and then switches to the right half when you mouseover the image (i.e., the search image).

tags.name: Release Notes
tags.description:
#### August 26, 2021
- New authorization scheme using header instead of signature.

#### August 15, 2019
- Updated documentation site with an entirely new design.

#### October 23, 2018
- Some matches may return an extremely large number of backlinks. We have added a default limit of 100 backlinks per match to keep results manageable. This limit can be modified or removed using the backlink_limit argument to the search call.
- Results to the [search call](#tag--Search-the-TinEye-index) can now be restricted to only [stock](https://help.tineye.com/article/252-what-are-stock-images) sites or [collection](https://help.tineye.com/article/251-what-are-image-collections) sites using the `tags` filter argument, or to a single domain using the `domain` filter argument.

#### March 19th, 2017
- Moved to the HMAC-SHA256 algorithm for API request signing. 
- If a match result comes from a domain associated with [stock](https://help.tineye.com/article/252-what-are-stock-images) or [collection](https://help.tineye.com/article/251-what-are-image-collections) images, this is shown in the `tags` list returned from the [search call](#tag--Search-the-TinEye-index). This replaces the contributor flag which was less specific and less flexible.
- The `stats` object has been updated with more data about the search response. The `total_backlinks`, `total_contributors` and `total_results` fields were moved to the `stats` section and the `total_contributors` field was split into `total_collection` and `total_stock`.
- The (remaining_searches)[https://services.tineye.com/developers/tineyeapi/#get-/remaining_searches/] method now returns information on all non-expired search bundles with remaining searches instead of only the active bundle. The `total_remaining_searches` field counts all the searches you have remaining.
- Added the `domain` field to the search results.
- Added the `match_score` field to the search results.

#### June 10th, 2015
- New TinEye API design.
- Search page updated with image collection domain filter.

#### May 11th, 2015
- Changed TinEye API search page to return the same sorting order as TinEye.com.

#### October 7th, 2014
- Added TinEye API Release notes page. The API Sandbox endpoint was moved from https://api.tineye.com/sandbox/ to https://api.tineye.com/rest/.

#### September 23th, 2014
- Changed HTTP status codes from 500 to 400 for requests that are either missing parameters or are erroneous (e.g. Query image is too simple, or a string is provided instead of an integer).

get.description: Search against an image given as a URL.

400.description:
## Bad Request

This usually occurs because the image file cannot be used with the TinEye
API, either because:
- the URL does not exist
- the image is corrupted or is not an image file
- the image is visually too simple or is too small in size

429.description:
## Too Many Requests

You may make multiple concurrent requests to the TinEye API.
However, depending on the load being experienced by the TinEye servers,
you may receive a “429 Too many requests” error
when making many simultaneous searches.
Please ensure that your code can either handle that error,
or that it waits for the current search to complete
before performing the next search.
If you regularly need to perform a high number of concurrent searches
please contact us with details about your requirements.

parameters.name: image_url
parameters.description: The publicly-accessible URL  at which the API can find the image  with which to search TinEye.

post.description:
The search image uploaded must be in either JPEG, PNG, WebP, GIF, BMP, AVIF, or TIFF format.
We do not support animations (such as animated GIFs, PNGs and WEBPs).

For optimal performance,
uploaded images should be at most 300px in size in the smallest dimension.
Images with both dimensions larger than 300px will be resized by the API.
For example, an image 800x600px in size will be resized to 400x300px.

400.description:
## Bad Request

This usually occurs because the image file cannot be used with the TinEye
API, either because:
- the URL does not exist
- the image is corrupted or is not an image file
- the image is visually too simple or is too small in size

429.description:
## Too Many Requests

You may make multiple concurrent requests to the TinEye API.
However, depending on the load being experienced by the TinEye servers,
you may receive a “429 Too many requests” error
when making many simultaneous searches.
Please ensure that your code can either handle that error,
or that it waits for the current search to complete
before performing the next search.
If you regularly need to perform a high number of concurrent searches
please contact us with details about your requirements.

image_upload.description: The image file with which to search TinEye.

get.description: Lists the number of searches you have left in your non-expired bundles.
Get the number of images indexed by TinEye.
